Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT
This project seeks to increase science literacy with regard to environmental change. Deliverables include 1) a two-hour public television program (Reinventing California) intended for public television broadcast; 2) five Place-Based Programs located at state and national parks in California; 3) an online educational portal with open source podcast videos and other resources for downloading and use in multiple settings. Intended audiences include California public television viewers, visitors to California state and national parks, and users on line educational resources. The secondary professional audience includes park interpretive staff, scientists, teachers, and media professionals. STEM content includes geology, evolution of species, biodiversity, and climate change. Through strategic partnerships with universities, government agencies, and public television this three year project is creating a new model that builds capacity, and impacts audiences in new ways. The project evaluation and research conducted by the Institute for Learning Innovation will look at how using media which provides an overarching sense of place within the environment can be integrated with place-based programs that add a personal scale to understanding environmental change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The California Environmental Legacy Project is a pioneering educational media project that was created to increase public understanding of environmental change and inspire a new culture of stewardship in America. With major funding from the National Science Foundation, the Legacy Project produced a public television documentary called Becoming California, a package of short films and video podcasts created for state and national park visitor centers across California, an educational website (www.calegacy.org) to deliver its media programs and connect with public and professional audiences, and companion K-12 teacher resources. The major goals of the Legacy Project were to inspire viewers and participants to explore how we shape and are shaped by environmental change and the nature of our relationship to the environment. The Legacy Project was created by a team of distinguished scientists, leading educators, and award-winning media professionals, along with a set of project partners, including Sacramento State, Humboldt State University, California State Parks, the National Park Service, the U.S. Geological Survey, the San Diego Natural History Museum, and the UC Davis John Muir Institute of the Environment.  Project team and partners worked together to create this innovative package of educational media and resources.

The Legacy Project was created to reach a broad and diverse public audience of California public television viewers, visitors to California state and national parks, and users of online educational resources, as well as a professional audience of park interpretive staff, scientists, teachers, and media professionals through professional development opportunities. For its public audiences, the project sought to increase understanding of environmental change, inspire interest in nature-based learning experiences, and to enhance interest in learning about science and the environment. For its professional audiences, the project sought to increase knowledge and understanding of environmental change among educators in their places of work, enhance their effectiveness at delivering science content to public audiences, and improve their capacity to use digital media as a learning tool.

As a result of National Science Foundation funding, the project produced an Emmy award winning documentary program called Becoming California that has broadcast over 240 times in 18 states and reached a potential audience of over 80 million viewers. The project’s state and national park films are being enjoyed by thousands of visitors to Anza Borrego Desert State Park, Baldwin Hills Scenic Overlook State Park (in Los Angeles), Lassen Volcanic National Park, Point Reyes National Seashore, and Redwood National and State Parks. Since its launch in 2011, the project website has received over 100,000 page views by over 35,000 users and videos posted on the project’s YouTube Channel have been viewed over 17,000 times. The project also has an active Twitter following that engages public and professional audiences about environmental change and exploring ways of building a new culture of stewardship in California. The project also has engaged park education staff and K-12 science teachers through its professional development activities and distribution of its educationl films for use in California parks and schools.
